content: The Day of Reckoning Has Come For Shady Data Companies Elliott Easterling Blocked Unblock Follow Following Mar 30, 2018 When Twine launched the TrueData initiative, we set out to represent the standard of truth in data — to review, vet, and verify all of our sources to make sure our data describes the real actions of real people, and that it is never modeled, assumed, or algorithmically-derived. But the recent controversy surrounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica highlights another key element of data truth: making sure that data respects user privacy and choice . The sharing of data is not going to go away — in the information age it is the basis for how many industries operate. The ability for publishers to farm out non-core parts of their business to technology partners means that they can focus on executing on the things they do best. It wouldn’t make sense for every single publisher to develop an ad network, or an image server, or a recommendation engine, or a payment system, or a ticketing platform, etc. These are all tiny slices of an overall site experience that publishers partner to deliver — and those partnerships require user data to function correctly. And let’s also be clear: advertising is also not going away. In a world where users balk at paying more than a few dollars for access to apps or websites, advertising helps compensate content creators for the value they bring. And digital advertising is fundamentally based on data; without it advertising is logarithmically less efficient. The sharing of behavioral, demographic, and interest data attached to anonymous identifiers like a cookie or a mobile ad ID helps make sure that married people don’t get ads for dating sites and millennials don’t get ads for AARP—it creates ads that are more useful for the user while saving money for advertisers. And if anything, mobile is even safer than desktop; as the gatekeepers for a large percentage of mobile apps and the traffic they generate, Apple and Google have focused on user privacy. But even they acknowledge that without advertising revenue the app ecosystem would collapse. So data sharing is here to stay. But what IS likely to go away — what Twine is hoping to actively usher away — is the era of shady data: data that is collected without particular regard to standards, regulations, or terms of service; that is stored without a sufficient level of care; that may or may not be accurate. All of this actively harms the systems that rely on data to make them work. If you believe that data sharing is important now, it will only become more important with time. “Machine learning” feels like a buzzword, but I also truly believe it’s the future. So much of the work that is now done manually and tediously can be taken over by AI. But without good, accurate, and ethically-sourced data on which to build those learning algorithms, you end up with another cliche: garbage in, garbage out. And part of this new era in data will be a new transparency around how data is collected, stored, and shared. Already Europe is leading the way in this with the General Data Privacy Regulation (GDPR) . We expect that this regulation will see a large number of shady EU data companies wiped off the map. Here in the U.S., our regulators have tended to be more laissez faire about matters like data collection, leaving it to industry groups and individual companies to craft guidelines and ensure that they are followed. It remains to be see if any state or federal regulations will follow in the wake of the current Facebook story, but even if they don’t the overall trend is toward giving users more information, protection, and choice as it relates to digital advertising. Users must be 100% anonymous. They must be able to opt out of data collection, at any point in their relationship with a company, and that opt-out must be honored among the entire chain of partnerships a company has. There must be process and technology in place for user privacy and choice at any company that deals with data. And user privacy and choice must become something that is an active part of product conversations, not just something a company leaves to their lawyers, in hopes they don’t have to deal with. To be responsible members of the data community, we all have to step up and commit to doing more. It’s time to bring data into the light.
title_html: The Day of Reckoning Has Come For Shady Data Companies
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

The Day of Reckoning Has Come For Shady Data Companies

Elliott Easterling
Mar 30, 2018

When Twine launched the TrueData initiative, we set out to represent the standard of truth in data — to review, vet, and verify all of our sources to make sure our data describes the real actions of real people, and that it is never modeled, assumed, or algorithmically-derived.

But the recent controversy surrounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica highlights another key element of data truth: making sure that data respects user privacy and choice.

The sharing of data is not going to go away — in the information age it is the basis for how many industries operate. The ability for publishers to farm out non-core parts of their business to technology partners means that they can focus on executing on the things they do best. It wouldn’t make sense for every single publisher to develop an ad network, or an image server, or a recommendation engine, or a payment system, or a ticketing platform, etc. These are all tiny slices of an overall site experience that publishers partner to deliver — and those partnerships require user data to function correctly.

And let’s also be clear: advertising is also not going away. In a world where users balk at paying more than a few dollars for access to apps or websites, advertising helps compensate content creators for the value they bring. And digital advertising is fundamentally based on data; without it advertising is logarithmically less efficient. The sharing of behavioral, demographic, and interest data attached to anonymous identifiers like a cookie or a mobile ad ID helps make sure that married people don’t get ads for dating sites and millennials don’t get ads for AARP—it creates ads that are more useful for the user while saving money for advertisers. And if anything, mobile is even safer than desktop; as the gatekeepers for a large percentage of mobile apps and the traffic they generate, Apple and Google have focused on user privacy. But even they acknowledge that without advertising revenue the app ecosystem would collapse. So data sharing is here to stay.

But what IS likely to go away — what Twine is hoping to actively usher away — is the era of shady data: data that is collected without particular regard to standards, regulations, or terms of service; that is stored without a sufficient level of care; that may or may not be accurate. All of this actively harms the systems that rely on data to make them work.

If you believe that data sharing is important now, it will only become more important with time. “Machine learning” feels like a buzzword, but I also truly believe it’s the future. So much of the work that is now done manually and tediously can be taken over by AI. But without good, accurate, and ethically-sourced data on which to build those learning algorithms, you end up with another cliche: garbage in, garbage out.

And part of this new era in data will be a new transparency around how data is collected, stored, and shared. Already Europe is leading the way in this with the General Data Privacy Regulation (GDPR). We expect that this regulation will see a large number of shady EU data companies wiped off the map.

Here in the U.S., our regulators have tended to be more laissez faire about matters like data collection, leaving it to industry groups and individual companies to craft guidelines and ensure that they are followed. It remains to be see if any state or federal regulations will follow in the wake of the current Facebook story, but even if they don’t the overall trend is toward giving users more information, protection, and choice as it relates to digital advertising.

Users must be 100% anonymous. They must be able to opt out of data collection, at any point in their relationship with a company, and that opt-out must be honored among the entire chain of partnerships a company has. There must be process and technology in place for user privacy and choice at any company that deals with data. And user privacy and choice must become something that is an active part of product conversations, not just something a company leaves to their lawyers, in hopes they don’t have to deal with.

To be responsible members of the data community, we all have to step up and commit to doing more. It’s time to bring data into the light.

  • Privacy

  • Elliott Easterling

    Founder and CEO of TrueData. www.TrueData.co

title: The Day of Reckoning Has Come For Shady Data Companies
content_html:
The Day of Reckoning Has Come For Shady Data Companies

Elliott Easterling
Mar 30, 2018

When Twine launched the TrueData initiative, we set out to represent the standard of truth in data — to review, vet, and verify all of our sources to make sure our data describes the real actions of real people, and that it is never modeled, assumed, or algorithmically-derived.

But the recent controversy surrounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica highlights another key element of data truth: making sure that data respects user privacy and choice.

The sharing of data is not going to go away — in the information age it is the basis for how many industries operate. The ability for publishers to farm out non-core parts of their business to technology partners means that they can focus on executing on the things they do best. It wouldn’t make sense for every single publisher to develop an ad network, or an image server, or a recommendation engine, or a payment system, or a ticketing platform, etc. These are all tiny slices of an overall site experience that publishers partner to deliver — and those partnerships require user data to function correctly.

And let’s also be clear: advertising is also not going away. In a world where users balk at paying more than a few dollars for access to apps or websites, advertising helps compensate content creators for the value they bring. And digital advertising is fundamentally based on data; without it advertising is logarithmically less efficient. The sharing of behavioral, demographic, and interest data attached to anonymous identifiers like a cookie or a mobile ad ID helps make sure that married people don’t get ads for dating sites and millennials don’t get ads for AARP—it creates ads that are more useful for the user while saving money for advertisers. And if anything, mobile is even safer than desktop; as the gatekeepers for a large percentage of mobile apps and the traffic they generate, Apple and Google have focused on user privacy. But even they acknowledge that without advertising revenue the app ecosystem would collapse. So data sharing is here to stay.

But what IS likely to go away — what Twine is hoping to actively usher away — is the era of shady data: data that is collected without particular regard to standards, regulations, or terms of service; that is stored without a sufficient level of care; that may or may not be accurate. All of this actively harms the systems that rely on data to make them work.

If you believe that data sharing is important now, it will only become more important with time. “Machine learning” feels like a buzzword, but I also truly believe it’s the future. So much of the work that is now done manually and tediously can be taken over by AI. But without good, accurate, and ethically-sourced data on which to build those learning algorithms, you end up with another cliche: garbage in, garbage out.

Already Europe is leading the way in this with the General Data Privacy Regulation (GDPR). We expect that this regulation will see a large number of shady EU data companies wiped off the map.

Here in the U.S., our regulators have tended to be more laissez faire about matters like data collection, leaving it to industry groups and individual companies to craft guidelines and ensure that they are followed. It remains to be see if any state or federal regulations will follow in the wake of the current Facebook story, but even if they don’t the overall trend is toward giving users more information, protection, and choice as it relates to digital advertising.

Users must be 100% anonymous. They must be able to opt out of data collection, at any point in their relationship with a company, and that opt-out must be honored among the entire chain of partnerships a company has. There must be process and technology in place for user privacy and choice at any company that deals with data. And user privacy and choice must become something that is an active part of product conversations, not just something a company leaves to their lawyers, in hopes they don’t have to deal with.

To be responsible members of the data community, we all have to step up and commit to doing more. It’s time to bring data into the light.
